docs.lead_paragraph: THE soul of Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman'' looms behind the small, unthreatening revival of the play, now at the Eugene O'Neill Theater, like the promise of a fierce, revivifying midsummer storm. You await its imminent arrival, the signs being right. As you watch the play being performed, you could swear there are shifty winds around you, intermittently turning the leaves of the oak trees pale-side-up. In the distance, you can almost see dark roiling cumulus clouds and flashes of lightning, but the play's sharp claps of thunder and their ominous reverberations remain muted. Even the short, intense downpours -- sudden theatrical explosions that briefly engage the emotions -- are the kind that Midwestern farmers dismiss as ''spoilers.'' The water evaporates before soaking into the earth. Finally, the play's angry, disembodied soul moves along the far horizon and vanishes entirely.

headline.main: For This 'Salesman,' A Soft Sell Is the Way

docs.abstract: Vincent Canby reviews revival of Arthur Miller play Death of a Salesman, starring Brian Dennehy; reviews Classic Stage Co performance of Martin Crimp's adaptation of Moliere's The Misanthrope; Roger Rees and Uma Thurman star; Canby reviews James Naughton's one-man show James Naughton: Street of Derams; drawing; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was 70 years ago this summer that Goodyear first decided to come south out of Ohio, looking for workers eager to mold rubber into tires for low wages, and the vast plateau of a factory the company built here eventually became one of the largest in the world. The decision was a critical moment in the economic recovery of the South. But the plant's wages are not low anymore, and now, tens of millions of tires later, the never-ending search for greater efficiency has finally left northeastern Alabama behind. This month, in a move attributed in part to the Asian and Latin American economic crises, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced that it would cease making tires at what it called its ''inefficient'' Gadsden plant, leaving only a small rubber-making operation and wiping out more than 1,300 jobs. When the final tire rolls out of the immense factory later this year, this city will face a cloudy future -- one for which it has spent more than a decade worrying and planning.

headline.main: Search for Efficiency Now Leaves Alabama Town Behind

docs.abstract: Gadsden, Ala, after over decade of worrying and planning, faces Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co plan to stop making tires in city and cut 1,300 jobs; employment at plant fell sharply from post-war height as company failed to make needed high-tech investments, even as unionized workers agreed to host of conessions to save jobs; final cut will test city's extensive economic diversification efforts; map; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Government will begin enlisting millions of Medicare beneficiaries in its war against Medicare fraud next week, urging them to report billing errors, overcharges and other evidence of possible wrongdoing by their doctors and hospitals. The campaign has strong support from lobbyists for the elderly, who see it as a way to educate consumers and save money for Medicare and its beneficiaries.

headline.main: U.S. Is Asking for Patients' Help In Fight Against Medicare Fraud

docs.abstract: Government plans drive to educate Medicare beneficiaries to report billing errors, overcharges and possible fraud by their doctors and hospitals; lobbyists for elderly strongly back drive; doctors express outrage; Health Sec Donna E Shalala, Attorney Gen Janet Reno and Federal Bureau of Investigation Dir Louis J Freeh will speak to beneficiaries at 30 sites linked by satellite (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE huge lobbying battle over the future of Medicare, the Federal health program for elderly and disabled Americans, is expected to turn even fiercer after a bipartisan commission issues its recommendations, expected on March 1. Interest groups with immense stakes in both the direction and the details of any reorganization of Medicare include some of America's deepest-pocketed lobbies: physicians, hospital chains, pharmaceutical companies, health maintenance organizations and employers who pay insurance premiums for their retirees.

headline.main: Five Perspectives on the Business of Reshaping Medicare

docs.abstract: Lobbying campaign over future of Medicare is expected to become even fiercer after bipartisan commission issues its recommendations; hospitals, physicians, health plan operators, employers and drug companies each have their own perspective; drawing (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

byline.original: By MILT FREUDENHEIM and DAVID J. MORROW

docs.lead_paragraph: For several weeks now, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have been starring in a shadow play titled ''Senate 2000,'' garnering top billing in a race they have yet to join officially. But while Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Clinton coyly deflect questions about their intentions, their would-be understudies -- Representatives Nita M. Lowey and Rick A. Lazio -- are quietly campaigning in the wings, positioning themselves to step into the bright lights should the headliners fall from grace or off the political stage.

headline.main: As Giuliani and First Lady Ponder, 2 Others Wait in Wings

docs.abstract: Rep Nita M Lowey, Democrat, and Rep Rick A Lazio, Republican, wait in wings until Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani decide whether to enter race for Senate from New York; both Lowey and Lazio are quietly campaigning in wings, positioning themselves to step into bright lights should headliners fall from grace or off political stage; in upstate New York, Lowey and Lazio are meeting potential contributors, road-testing their messages, gauging support of local kingmakers and trying to broaden their paper-thin name recognition; both must constantly parry skepticism of local politicians and reporters who view them as dark horses; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: REMEMBER Medicare? With all the attention these days focused on President Clinton's proposal to salvage Social Security, it is easy to forget that Medicare -- the program that provides about 39 million elderly and disabled Americans with basic health insurance -- is riddled with far deeper, more imminently threatening financial problems. Medicare's trust fund will run out of money as early as 2008 (compared with 2032 for Social Security's). And because the elderly are living longer and medical costs are rising faster than most other prices, Medicare costs are going up more quickly than spending by Social Security.

headline.main: For Medicare, A Rocky Road To Competition

docs.abstract: Stuart Altman and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, economists on Federal commission appointed to fix Medicare, hold deciding votes on whether commission will forward to Congress a proposal favored by Sen John B Breaux, chairman, and nine other members to scrap existing system in favor of creating a market for competing public and private plans; agree that competition is needed to modernize a sclerotic Medicare system, but they are pushing for specific set of benefits, including coverage for prescription drugs, which Medicare does not now provide; Breaux is willing to concede something to Tyson and Altman but not so much that he would lose support of Republicans worried about adding new benefits before Medicare's financial predicament is settled; thus, what began as high-minded debate over competition could quickly become an old-fashioned spat over money; photo; graphs (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Kiran Joshi, showing the same kind of fatigue that she remembers from her days as an intern and resident, cradled her face in her hands and slowly kneaded her forehead. For the last three months, the days have been long and uncertain at the HIP Health Plans of New Jersey clinic where she has worked as an obstetrician and gynecologist for 15 years. The clinic here is one of the 23 facilities owned by the financially dooomed HIP that the state plans to close by March 31. Like a retail store advertising a going-out-of-business sale, the traffic has been brisk with patients eager for the remnants of the health care they once knew.

headline.main: Headache and Heartache of Losing Health Care

docs.abstract: Hectic scene at HIP Health Plan of New Jersey clinic in Paramus described in light of plan to close it and 22 other facilities by March 31; patients and doctors comment; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MOIRA LYONS, like many of her neighbors, was disturbed by a pungent odor that overtook the Shippan section of Stamford 20 years ago. Complaints from residents of the peninsula that juts into Long Island Sound had proved unavailing. And so it was that Ms. Lyons and some neighbors banded together in the 70's to try to eliminate the stench. Everyone believed that the smell was coming from the municipal incinerator on McGee Avenue, a few miles from the eastern end of Shippan, which has multimillion-dollar shorefront houses and whose centerpiece is the Stamford Yacht Club.

headline.main: A Master Legislator Steps Up to Speaker

docs.abstract: Article on Moira Lyons of Stamford, Conn, who has become first woman to hold post of General Assembly Speaker; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In response to prodding from a state court, insurance regulators seeking to liquidate the insolvent HIP Health Plan of New Jersey today unveiled a detailed transition plan intended to ease policyholders into new coverage with as little disruption as possible. Under the plan, the 165,000 members of HIP, the state's fourth largest health maintenance organization, will be allowed to keep their current doctors for at least 30 days beyond the scheduled March 31 closing of HIP's 23 treatment centers, regardless of whether those doctors have a relationship with the new insurer.

headline.main: State Offers New Protections for Patients in Failed H.M.O.

docs.lead_paragraph: After a day of tense negotiations, the Roundabout Theater Company and the stagehands union have agreed on part of a new contract, averting a disruption at the hit musical ''Cabaret.'' The agreement will increase the number of higher-paid unionized workers to 23 from 3 at the show, playing at Studio 54. Further details of the contract agreement were not available.
